group_1.textCenter: I'd like ten more days to prepare our troops.

group_1.textRight: Very well. We can afford that amount of time@without compromising our plans.
You shall prepare enough men to attack Taito@from the north.

group_1.textLeft: I will.
So then, are we carrying out a three-way@pincer attack?

group_1.textRight: Indeed.

group_1.narration: ―Kumai―@We'll attack these ways: Hokuyo from the north,@Kosho from the west, and Nagitsu from the south.
―Kumai―@According to our surveys, defenses in the north are thin,@while the west and south are strongly fortified.
―Kumai―@Thus, we've arranged the troops so that Mizuna,@governing Hokuyo, approaches from the north.
―Kumai―@The western front will have our main forces,@including my and Lord Sumiya's troops.
―Kumai―@The southern front will be bolstered@with the remaining men.
―Kumai―@The Taito Gang will have no choice@but to divide their forces.

group_1.textLeft: Still, it seems we'll be the only ones@attacking the north…

group_1.textRight: If all aligns with our surveys, there should@be no problem.
Hokuyo is also mountainous, so it should be@a trifle for you to hold the high ground.

group_1.textLeft: …And would it be all right to use a beacon@as a signal to attack?

group_1.textRight: I'll leave that decision to you.

group_1.textLeft: Understood.

group_1.textRight: I thought it would be too difficult to convince@Mizuna to join this battle.
Perhaps I was overthinking it.

group_1.textLeft: I changed my mind after listening@to Gen'un's story.

group_1.textRight: If I were in your position, I'd be frightened.
I expect you to be fully committed@to this challenge.

group_1.textLeft: Yes…
There's only one route from Endless Hell@to Taito Village.
You cannot reach it even if you cut through@other roads or mountains.

group_1.textRight: I don't understand why the village would@have just one entrance.

group_1.textLeft: If it's blocked, the Taito Gang will be@utterly unable to escape.
You could say that's the price of maximum@defense.

group_1.textRight: Mm. So what are the surroundings like?

group_1.textLeft: Near the entrance of the village, there is@an open area for the soldiers to maneuver,
similar to a cavalry corridor in a castle.
If we increase the mobility of our troops,@we should be able to catch them off-guard.

group_1.textRight: Then if we surround them, we can take them@all out in one fell swoop.

group_1.textLeft: Even if their weapons are superior to ours,@and their stature more menacing,
they have the same human limitations@as we do.

group_1.textCenter: Please take note of the enemy placements@in Endless Hell.
There's a chance that enemies are lurking@in the marked locations.

group_1.textRight: Excuse me, sir!
This letter is from Lord Kumai himself.

group_1.textLeft: Hmm…
…They've set the date of the campaign.
Attention!

group_1.textRight: Yes, sir.

group_1.textLeft: We'll open with archery fire and then storm in.@I will direct our formation from there.

group_1.textRight: So everything in Endless Hell has been@completely exposed…
But thanks to Tsuyu, we know what they're@planning, too.

group_1.textLeft: If what you've said is true, we're in for a hell@of a reckoning…
If Endless Hell won't stop them, then it doesn't@matter how many men we can each kill.
I suppose it's true what they say:
Someday, you will meet your limit.

group_1.textRight: That's why we're trying to turn things around.

group_1.textLeft: But it's taking a long time for you to kill@a single monk.

group_1.textRight: We tried assassinating Sumiya and Kumai, too,@but we couldn't get past their defenses.
If we could just find a weak point in Brother@Baldie's defenses…

group_1.textLeft: I sent one of our best assassins after him,@but they failed and returned.
And if you can't manage it either, we might@as well give up on an ambush.

group_1.textRight: Sorry…

group_1.textLeft: There's nothing more to it.@We'll fight to the limit ourselves.

group_1.textRight: …Although we're the ones who'll be under@attack, I've been spying on my dad just in case.
He doesn't seem to be plotting anything,@though.

group_1.textLeft: I managed to infiltrate Lord Sango's mansion…
But even after everything we learned,@we didn't find anything suspicious.

group_1.textRight: Yes…it seemed like everyone was just trying@to survive the losses from the famine.
What about Tsuyu's dad?

group_1.textLeft: Putting a permanent end to a problem that's@been plaguing us for centuries…
He and I seem to share the same doubts.
But considering his position, he can't simply@ignore Sumiya and Kumai.
If he rebels, everyone in the Mizuna Clan@will suffer, even nobles like you.

group_1.textRight: And what about that bastard monk Gen'un?

group_1.textLeft: I suspect it's because of our doubts against@the campaign on Taito,
but he refuses to see me now,@even at my father's request.

group_1.textRight: I guess it's not worth risking us Battle@Shamaness going on the warpath.
I mean, if Sana can sneak into Lord Sango's@mansion, she could take down the monk, too.

group_1.textLeft: Huh…?!

group_1.textRight: …Kidding. It's my job to do the dirty work.

group_1.textLeft: But not even you have been able to get close@to Gen'un, right?

group_1.textRight: Maybe he's got bullshit monk powers that let@him see things he otherwise couldn't.
At the very least, he's got a keen intuition…
Doesn't matter how carefully I move and@conceal myself... He sees right through me.
The guy's a total beast. I felt that as early as@our duel during the first battle of Taito.

group_1.textLeft: We can't dissuade him from his ambitions,@nor can we strike at him from the shadows…

group_1.textRight: There's nothing more we can do…is there…?

group_1.textLeft: The attack is coming right up tomorrow,@so even if we come up with something…

group_1.textRight: Tonight is our last chance.@I'll try infiltrating Suitoku one last time.

group_1.textLeft: Don't push yourself too hard.

group_1.textRight: My whole family is in serious danger.@If anything, I can't push myself enough.
